item.content:encoded:
Ghost is a blogging platform that's known for being user friendly and beautiful straight out of the box. Github Pages is a static site host on Github for hosting simple blogs and landing pages for open-source projects.

Starting out

Create a folder to hold Ghost and static files. 

$ cd <to_desired_location>
$ mkdir <ghost_folder_name> && cd <ghost_folder_name>

Make sure you have Node and Python (default on apple macs).

Installing homebrew (OSX package manager).

/usr/bin/ruby -e "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/master/install)"

Installing wget, a tool used to retrieve content from web servers. With homebrew installed, we can run the following.

$ brew update
$ brew install wget

Installing Buster and Pip(python package manager).

# go to your ghost's directory
$ cd <ghost_folder_name>

# if you don't have pip
$ sudo easy_install pip

# install buster
$ sudo pip install buster

Installing Ghost and start your local Ghost server.

# gets the latest version of ghost
$ wget https://ghost.org/zip/ghost-latest.zip

# unzips ghost
$ unzip ghost-latest.zip

# installs dependencies
$ npm install

$ npm start

npm start starts the Node.js server that will serve up the admin interface at http://localhost:2368/ghost. Here is where you will create an account and manage all your contents and fancy settings.

Coming together

On github create a new repo [your-github-username].github.io.

NOTE: the format must be [your-github-username].github.io. Otherwise it will not work.

# current terminal tab is running so...
# (in a new tab) get back to the ghost folder
$ cd <ghost_folder_name>

$ buster setup --gh-repo=\
"https://github.com/<username>/<username>.github.io.git"

$ buster generate

$ buster deploy

buster generate will create all of the appropriate directories, HTML pages and links for your entire Ghost blog within that folder.

buster deploy, adds, commits and pushes the changes you generated up to your blog's repo.

To exit hit Ctrl-C in the tab running Ghost's server.

recap

$ npm start
$ buster generate
$ buster deploy

enjoy.

item.content:encoded:
You're live! Nice. We've put together a little post to introduce you to the Ghost editor and get you started. You can manage your content by signing in to the admin area at <your blog URL>/ghost/. When you arrive, you can select this post from a list on the left and see a preview of it on the right. Click the little pencil icon at the top of the preview to edit this post and read the next section!

Getting Started

Ghost uses something called Markdown for writing. Essentially, it's a shorthand way to manage your post formatting as you write!

Writing in Markdown is really easy. In the left hand panel of Ghost, you simply write as you normally would. Where appropriate, you can use shortcuts to style your content. For example, a list:

  • Item number one
  • Item number two
    • A nested item
  • A final item

or with numbers!

  1. Remember to buy some milk
  2. Drink the milk
  3. Tweet that I remembered to buy the milk, and drank it

Links

Want to link to a source? No problem. If you paste in a URL, like http://ghost.org - it'll automatically be linked up. But if you want to customise your anchor text, you can do that too! Here's a link to the Ghost website. Neat.

What about Images?

Images work too! Already know the URL of the image you want to include in your article? Simply paste it in like this to make it show up:

Not sure which image you want to use yet? That's ok too. Leave yourself a descriptive placeholder and keep writing. Come back later and drag and drop the image in to upload:

Quoting

Sometimes a link isn't enough, you want to quote someone on what they've said. Perhaps you've started using a new blogging platform and feel the sudden urge to share their slogan? A quote might be just the way to do it!

Ghost - Just a blogging platform

Working with Code

Got a streak of geek? We've got you covered there, too. You can write inline <code> blocks really easily with back ticks. Want to show off something more comprehensive? 4 spaces of indentation gets you there.

.awesome-thing {
    display: block;
    width: 100%;
}

Ready for a Break?

Throw 3 or more dashes down on any new line and you've got yourself a fancy new divider. Aw yeah.

Advanced Usage

There's one fantastic secret about Markdown. If you want, you can write plain old HTML and it'll still work! Very flexible.

That should be enough to get you started. Have fun - and let us know what you think :)
